title: A Sharp Warning About Donald Trump
description: Readers discuss an editorial that one called “the full-throated condemnation of Donald Trump that the facts demand.” Also: Taylor Swift; trucking; Canadian hockey.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Rothchild
title: For Gaza’s Pregnant Women and Newborns, the War Will Never Be Over
description: Even if the war ends tomorrow, its effects will last a lifetime for new mothers and their children.
content: After Israel began its invasion of Gaza shortly after Hamas’s attack on Oct. 7, Aya Khrais — a pregnant 26-year-old dentist, wife of a doctor and mother of a 2-year-old girl living in Gaza City — lost contact with the doctors and health services she needed for prenatal care and for managing her diabetes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: World Bank Warns of Energy Price Surge if Mideast War Spreads
description: A new economic report predicted a year of weak growth and said the world faced a decade of “wasted opportunity.”
content: The global economy is at risk of a “wasted” decade and the weakest stretch of growth in 30 years, the World Bank warned on Tuesday, saying a sluggish recovery from the pandemic and crippling wars in Ukraine and the Middle East are expected to weigh heavily on output.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: portentous
description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word portentous has appeared in 25 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 3 in “Is Fluminense the Team of the Future?” by Rory Smith:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Boeing’s Max 9 Crisis Deepens
description: Safety checks have uncovered loose bolts on the grounded jetliners, raising more questions for management over how the top-selling planes are built.
content: The trouble at Boeing is deepening after safety inspectors at Alaska Airlines and United Airlines found loose bolts on some grounded 737 Max jetliners, drawing scrutiny to the quality control process for one of the world’s best-selling aircraft models.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Menendez, in Defiant Speech, Says Bribery Case Against Him Is ‘Baseless’
description: Senator Robert Menendez accused prosecutors of conducting a public smear campaign and denied accepting bribes to benefit the governments of Egypt and Qatar.
content: Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, took to the Senate floor on Tuesday to deny charges that he accepted bribes to benefit the governments of Egypt and Qatar and defiantly warned colleagues that they could be next.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Norway Moves to Allow Seabed Mining Exploration
description: The decision in Parliament, opposed by environmentalists, will allow prospectors to start surveying the country’s waters.
content: The Norwegian Parliament voted on Tuesday to authorize the opening of parts of the Norwegian Sea to seabed mining exploration, a move that reflects rising international demand for the metals needed to build batteries for electric vehicles worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Biden Is Trying to Jolt Us Out of Learned Helplessness About Trump
description: We need to stay outraged about the ex-president’s plot against America.
content: After Joe Biden’s speech on Friday marking the anniversary of the Jan. 6 insurrection and laying out the democratic stakes of the next election, Mitt Romney pronounced himself unimpressed. “As a Biden campaign theme, I think the ‘threat to democracy’ pitch is a bust,” the Utah Republican told a New York Times reporter. “Biden needs fresh material, a new attack, rather than kicking a dead political horse.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford and Jay Root
title: In New York, Hochul Says State of the State Is Concerning, but Fixable
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul, in her annual State of the State address, trumpeted her achievements while highlighting a series of intractable problems facing New York.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Tuesday presented a stark view of New York’s challenges, highlighting crime, a failing mental health infrastructure and affordability concerns as vexing challenges that her administration was ready to tackle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Here are the lawyers arguing the case.
description: Arguing for the special counsel: James I. Pearce, a career federal prosecutor who played a role in some Jan. 6 cases; and for former President Donald Trump, D. John Sauer, a former solicitor general of Missouri.
content: The two lawyers who will be squaring off in court on Tuesday to debate the issue of whether former President Donald J. Trump is immune to charges of trying to overturn the 2020 election both have experience in high-profile appeals, but they come from different sides of the legal aisle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: New York City Hid Realities of Homelessness Crisis, Report Finds
description: City officials manipulated public data for years and delayed reporting that homeless families had stayed overnight at an intake center instead of a shelter, according to a new investigation.
content: As New York City faced a worsening homelessness crisis in recent years, officials repeatedly sought to hide the reality on the ground, according to a city investigation released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Charlie Savage, Eileen Sullivan and Glenn Thrush
title: Appeals Court Seems Skeptical of Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: A three-judge panel appeared unlikely to grant the former president’s request that it throw out federal criminal charges that he plotted to overturn the 2020 election.
content: A federal appeals court expressed deep skepticism on Tuesday about former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election, suggesting that it is unlikely to rule in his favor on a central element of his defense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A City’s Campaign Against Homelessness Brings Stories of Violence
description: Local officials called for residents to deter the homeless in Kalispell, Mont., but unhoused residents said they were then accosted and attacked.
content: After watching a growing series of tents and other makeshift shelters spread into city parks and sidewalks, officials in northwestern Montana decided it was time for a crackdown on homelessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Is Poor Economic Sentiment All About MAGA?
description: Partisanship is having a huge effect on consumer surveys.
content: The economy is good, but Americans feel bad about it. Or do they?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Mary Wilson, Diana Nguyen, Stella Tan, Rachelle Bonja, Lexie Diao, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Pat McCusker and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Afterlife of a Gun
description: How communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market with guns slated for destruction.
content: Across the United States, hundreds of towns and cities are trying to get guns off the streets by turning them over to businesses that offer to destroy them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Why Are California’s Waters Lighting Up in Blue?
description: It looks like the trailer for “Avatar: The Way of Water,” but it’s a natural phenomenon. And spotting it is getting increasingly popular.
content: California seems to be off to a glowing start to the year — and we’re not just talking about Hollywood stars assembling for awards season. We’re talking about bioluminescent algae.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Wednesday Briefing: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court
description: Plus, 52 travel destinations for 2024.
content: At a hearing in Washington yesterday, judges expressed deep skepticism about Donald Trump’s claim that he was immune from charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election. Trump’s lawyers argued that he should not face prosecution because the charges stem from actions that he took as president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: OpenAI Says New York Times Lawsuit Against It Is ‘Without Merit’
description: The artificial intelligence start-up said that it collaborated with news organizations and that The Times, which accused it of copyright infringement, was not telling the full story.
content: OpenAI said on Monday that a New York Times lawsuit against it was “without merit” and that it supported and created opportunities for news organizations, as it waded further into a debate over the unauthorized use of published work to train artificial intelligence technologies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward, Isabel Kershner and Thomas Fuller
title: Israeli Strikes in Lebanon Kill Hezbollah Commander, Militia Says
description: The latest strikes across Israel’s northern border came as the U.S. secretary of state made another trip to the Middle East in efforts to prevent a wider war.
content: Israel launched strikes into southern Lebanon on Monday against Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militia, which said one of its senior commanders had been killed there, adding to concerns that Israel’s fight against Hamas in Gaza could erupt into a wider regional war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Jazmine Ulloa
title: Challenged on Policy Views in Town-Hall Event, Haley Doesn’t Budge
description: Nikki Haley took pointed questions from both Iowans and Fox News hosts.
content: Nikki Haley was repeatedly challenged over policy views that veer away from her more conservative rivals during an hourlong town-hall event on Fox News on Monday, but she stood her ground — and called Donald J. Trump an agent of chaos and Ron DeSantis a liar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: What Are Your Thoughts on Last Names?
description: Babies generally are given the father’s last name in the United States, but  a small minority of families are making different choices. What do you think?
content: How did you get your last name? Was it passed down to you from your father’s side of the family? That is how last names are usually given to babies in the United States, but some families are taking different approaches. They may draw from the mother’s side instead, use both parents’ last names (sometimes placing a hyphen between them), choose a name that has family history or other significance — or come up with something wholly original.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Editor of The Los Angeles Times Steps Down
description: Kevin Merida, who took over the job in 2021, said in an internal note that his last day would be on Friday.
content: When he joined The Los Angeles Times as its top editor nearly three years ago, Kevin Merida was hailed as a leader who would restore calm to a newsroom that had been buffeted by cost-cutting and corporate ownership battles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Delays Artemis Astronaut Moon Missions
description: Artemis II, a trip around the moon, will now occur no earlier than September 2025 while a moon landing, Artemis III, will move to 2026.
content: For NASA and its astronauts, the moon is no farther away in terms of distance, but it is slipping further into the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Blinken begins meetings in Israel amid deepening disagreements over the war.
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was meeting with top Israeli officials on Tuesday, continuing diplomatic efforts to avert a broader war in the region.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken was meeting with top Israeli officials on Tuesday, continuing diplomatic efforts to avert a broader war in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Jewish Group Assails Film Academy’s Diversity Efforts
description: An open letter signed by notable actors and producers criticized the organization for not including Jews as an underrepresented group as part of a new initiative.
content: More than 260 Jewish entertainment figures — including the actors David Schwimmer, Julianna Margulies and Josh Gad, and the producers Greg Berlanti and Marta Kauffman — signed an open letter to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts & Sciences on Tuesday, criticizing the organization for excluding Jews as an underrepresented group in its diversity efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Agrawal
title: This Venezuelan Family Won Asylum. Days Later, They Lost It.
description: Millions of asylum seekers have overwhelmed the immigration system. A confusing mix-up is keeping one family in limbo.
content: Dyluis Rojas and his wife and children fled first from Venezuela and later from Colombia and Chile, crossing deserts, jungles and rivers with one goal: to make it to the United States and stay there.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day:A ‘Leap Forward’ for A.I. May Occur in 2024
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 9, 2024.
content: “The rapid progress of A.I. will continue. It is inevitable.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: How to Discover Your Own Taste
description: Kyle Chayka on the art of developing personal style in an age when algorithms loom over aesthetics and culture.
content: Being on the internet just doesn’t feel as fun anymore. As more of our digital life is driven by algorithms, it’s become a lot easier to find movies or TV shows or music that fits our preferences pretty well. But it feels harder to find things that are strange and surprising — the kinds of culture that help you, as an individual, develop your own sense of taste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zeynep Tufekci
title: The Truth About Airplane Safety
description: The Japan Airlines and Alaska Airlines incidents could have been much worse.
content: It was only when I attempted to make small talk with my visibly squirming seatmate on a Raleigh-Durham to New York flight that I realized it was me causing that look of horror on his face, rather than the slight turbulence we had been experiencing since takeoff. A friendly chat, I had thought, might help distract him from flight anxiety. But then I noticed his eyes — wide with fear — were fixed on my computer screen, which displayed an investigative report on an airplane crash I had been reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sigrid Nunez
title: Waiting in the Snow for a Phone Call, Mixing Memory and Desire
description: Cynthia Zarin’s first novel, “Inverno,” is a tale of a woman’s incurable longing and haunted past.
content: I once taught a seminar for graduate fiction writers called A Poet’s Prose. The reading list consisted of prose works written by distinguished contemporary poets. I was surprised to find that several students had registered for the course because they considered their own writing poetic. I was less surprised to find that what they meant by poetic was exactly the kind of strained, showy language I’d hoped exposure to writers with a poet’s essential skills would improve. I wanted my students to read good poets’ prose for the same reason I kept encouraging them to read poetry: to learn how effective concision of language, meticulous use of detail and sensitivity to cadence can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: In South Carolina, Biden and Harris Test Policy-Heavy Pitch to Black Voters
description: The president’s re-election campaign is looking to rekindle support among a group that was pivotal to his 2020 victory, in a state that revived his candidacy.
content: As Democrats amplify their concerns about President Biden’s status with Black voters, South Carolina has emerged as a proving ground for his campaign: one where he can test his message to a predominantly Black electorate and use it as a largely ceremonial launchpad for his re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Unstoppable in Red
description: As Tiger Woods ends his relationship with Nike, the sporting world will say goodbye to an iconic look that was intimidating in its consistency.
content: When Tiger Woods locked in on the final day of the Masters in 2019, it felt like the sporting world had stepped into a time machine. The 43-year-old golfer — 11 years removed from winning his last major tournament — was fighting against a series of devastating injuries and an entirely new generation of competition but with every precision shot he was reminding the world what he once was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: New York Times journalists get a glimpse inside a devastated Gaza.
description: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.
content: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: A Hack of the S.E.C.’s Social Media Account Caused a Bitcoin Frenzy, Briefly
description: The X account of the Securities and Exchange Commission announced the approval of an investment product linked to Bitcoin. It wasn’t true.
content: For 15 minutes, the cryptocurrency industry was euphoric.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Herman Raucher, Screenwriter Best Known for ‘Summer of ’42,’ Dies at 95
description: His screenplay, based on his own youthful experience, was nominated for an Oscar. His other films included “Sweet November,” based on his own unproduced play.
content: Herman Raucher, who turned his memories of a summer as a teenager in a Massachusetts beach town, which included a sexual encounter with a young war widow, into the screenplay for the nostalgic 1971 film “Summer of ’42,” died on Dec. 28 in Stamford, Conn. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: A Former Twitter Exec Builds His Dream House in Wine Country
description: Bruce Falck, who left Twitter during Elon Musk’s takeover bid, had other things on his mind: completing a longed-for family home in Northern California.
content: Bruce Falck long dreamed of following the example set by his father, who ran a construction company in Johannesburg, South Africa: He wanted to build a house designed specifically for his family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Sweeney
title: Can I Fix the Spider Veins on My Face?
description: These broken blood vessels can be unsightly, but they’re not a nuisance you have to live with.
content: Q: I’ve noticed some red, squiggly blood vessels just under the skin of my cheeks and around my nose. What are they, exactly? And is it possible to get rid of them?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Oct. 7 Assaults, Including Sexual Violence, Could Be Crimes Against Humanity, 2 U.N. Experts Say
description: The experts’ statement came after the United Nations had been the focus of months of frustrated accusations that it was ignoring the rape and mutilation of women during the Oct. 7 attacks.
content: Violence that included sexual atrocities committed during the Hamas-led attacks on Oct. 7 in Israel amounts to war crimes and may also be crimes against humanity, two United Nations human rights experts said on Monday, following months of frustrated accusations from Israel and women’s groups that the U.N. was ignoring the rape and sexual mutilation of women during the Oct. 7 invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Sauers
title: Buy American? Easier Said Than Done.
description: In “Making It in America,” Rachel Slade examines the challenges of domestic production through the lens of one Maine company.
content: Is it possible to buy American in an age of offshoring? And is that the right goal — for workers, consumers or the planet? The journalist Rachel Slade explores these questions in “Making It in America,” which takes as a case study one small clothing manufacturer in Maine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Jimmy Kimmel Isn’t Expecting an Apology From Aaron Rodgers
description: Kimmel said although the N.F.L. star may believe that Kimmel is linked to Jeffrey Epstein, it’s more likely that Rodgers “is mad at me for making fun of his topknot.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Alan Feuer
title: Ray Epps, Target of Jan. 6 Conspiracy Theory, Is Sentenced to Probation
description: The onetime Trump supporter was driven into hiding after Fox News and prominent Republicans spread a false narrative that he was a government agent who helped instigate the attack on the Capitol.
content: Ray Epps, the former Trump supporter who became a target of a conspiracy theory that he was an undercover government agent who helped to instigate the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, was sentenced on Tuesday to a year of probation for his own small role in the riot instead of the six months in prison that prosecutors had requested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: State of the State: Hochul Unveils Her Agenda
description: In her speech, Gov. Kathy Hochul will propose providing leave for prenatal care, changing the way reading is taught and promoting artificial intelligence research.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday, the day Gov. Kathy Hochul is to deliver her State of the State address. We’ll find out what to listen for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Eileen Sullivan and Glenn Thrush
title: As Political Theater, Trump’s Court Appearance Wasn’t a Showstopper
description: The former president plans to continue showing up at various legal proceedings against him, but in this case the spotlight stayed largely on the judges and their skepticism about his immunity claims.
content: If Donald J. Trump’s goal on Tuesday was to turn a weighty legal proceeding in Washington into a de facto campaign appearance that galvanized media attention, he fell short.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: In Speech, New Jersey Governor Backs Phonics and Medical Debt Relief
description: “Nobody should have to worry about being able to afford critical health care,” Gov. Philip D. Murphy said in his sixth-annual State of the State address.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey embraced proposals to make it easier to build affordable housing and cut out-of-pocket expenses for abortions in his annual State of the State address on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: A Giant Vegas-Style Sphere in London? Don’t Bet on It.
description: The American developer MSG Entertainment withdrew its bid to build a sister arena in Britain after opposition from Londoners and the city’s mayor.
content: What happens in Vegas, it turns out, really does stay in Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Imagine if Trump Loses
description: Resistance to his candidacy is not futile.
content: The outcome of the 2016 presidential election was such a shocking event that for people of a certain cast of mind, Donald Trump is less a politician than a force of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Don’t Be Surprised if Trump Starts Attacking the Fed
description: Forewarned is forearmed: It will be bad-faith bullying.
content: Interest rates are heading down. Maybe not today, and maybe not tomorrow, but soon, and for the rest of this year (at least).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wilson
title: A Famous Explorer, an Obsessive Son and the Reappearance of Flag No. 98
description: Adm. Richard E. Byrd was once known around the world for his expeditions to Antarctica. His son was determined to preserve his legacy.
content: It arrived without fanfare or explanation, marked Lot No. 313 at the J. James Auction House in Plymouth, Mass. A simple flag, bearing an “E” and a “C” alongside a compass star, against a red, white and blue background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Tuesday Briefing
description: Israel’s next phase of the war in Gaza.
content: Israel said its military was starting to shift from a large-scale ground-and-air campaign in the Gaza Strip to a more targeted phase, with fewer troops and airstrikes, in its war against Hamas. Israeli officials have privately told their U.S. counterparts that they hoped the transition would be completed by the end of the month, U.S. officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Art’s Colonial Legacy: ‘It Would Have Been Better Not to Have Needed Museums.’
description: In this short film, Congolese artworks voice the poet and author Aimé Césaire’s words: “Colonization is thingification.”
content: The idea for this film began when a friend was planning an exhibition featuring Congolese artwork. She was considering including the documentary “Under the Black Mask” (1958), by the Belgian filmmaker Paul Haesaerts, but was unsure how to present the piece, which contains voice-over and images that stereotype and exoticize Congolese culture. How could we adequately contextualize a work by a filmmaker from Belgium created in the final years of that country’s decades-long, brutal colonial occupation of what is now the Democratic Republic of Congo?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘Remember How Obnoxious I Was?’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I’d been a disobedient teenager, eager to rebel against authority. I resisted my parents and the church. But oddly, the one adult I could actually talk to was our Presbyterian minister, Dr. Moffatt. We reunited recently for his 99th birthday. He surprised me by saying he’d once considered becoming a politician to impact peoples’ lives. “But you’ve impacted plenty of lives,” I responded. “Take me; remember how obnoxious I was?” “Oh, yes,” he said, smiling. “Remember being the only person who made me feel accepted and OK?” He nodded. Then, looking at me straight on, he said, “Lee, it’s called love.” — Lee Guthrie
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward, Anushka Patil and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Israel says it killed another Hezbollah commander after back-and-forth attacks.
description: A deadly airstrike further heightens tensions along Israel’s border with southern Lebanon.
content: The Israeli military said it killed a senior Hezbollah commander in an airstrike on Tuesday evening, further heightening tensions with the Iranian-backed militia after a day of back-and-forth attacks and the apparent Israeli killing of another Hezbollah commander on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Rebecca Robbins
title: Have You Been Overcharged for Prescription Drugs? We Want to Hear From You.
description: The New York Times is looking into pharmacy benefit managers, which play crucial roles in determining which medications your insurance covers and how much you pay.
content: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx. These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter C. Baker
title: In ‘My Friends’ an Exile Finds Himself Outside Libya, but Never Far Away
description: A rash decision to attend an anti-Qaddafi protest in London reverberates in Hisham Matar’s poignant and quietly suspenseful third novel.
content: In the works of the Libyan-born writer Hisham Matar, a few subjects take center stage again and again. There’s the violence of the Muammar el-Qaddafi regime: torture, assassination, disappearance, confessions broadcast on state television, government agents listening to phone calls. And there’s the experience of Libyans seeking safety in exile. Matar — himself one such exile — picks apart their psyches, analyzing at a microscopic level how violence and migration have altered how they think and feel and relate to the people closest to them. He has returned to this cluster of topics as if it’s a house he’s obsessed with, examining it from different angles, sneaking inside and finding new rooms, even new wings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: How to … : An Informational Writing Contest for Teenagers
description: We invite students to explain how to do any task in 400 words or fewer. Contest dates: Jan. 10 - Feb. 14, 2024
content: Do you know how to fix a brake light? What about how to memorize Shakespeare? How to keep a goldfish alive? Spot a shooting star? Write a love letter? Forgive someone?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manuela Andreoni
title: A New Era in Global Heat
description: Scientists are asking whether the planet’s warming is accelerating.
content: It’s confirmed: 2023 was the planet’s warmest year on record and perhaps in the last 100,000 years. By far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: A Weak Night for Trump? A DeSantis Flop? We Game Out Iowa.
description: A win isn’t always win in the Iowa caucuses. In the final days, the candidates are scrambling to beat each other — and expectations.
content: It may feel as if there is little suspense over who is likely to win the Republican presidential caucuses in Iowa on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By June Thomas
title: Aliens Have Never Been More Alluring
description: Why pop culture now flirts with extraterrestrials as much as it fears them.
content: Every generation gets the extraterrestrial invasion its times demand. In 1938, conflicts simmering in Europe meant that a radio broadcast of “The War of the Worlds” became a panic-inducing news event in America. In the McCarthy era, manufactured paranoia about Communists led to movies like “Invasion of the Body Snatchers” (1956) and “I Married a Monster From Outer Space” (1958). The terrors of the Cold War coincided with the skittering xenomorph of “Alien” (1979), a conscienceless creature willing to destroy humanity to ensure its own survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Defying Trump, G.O.P. Congressmen Hit the Road for DeSantis
description: A pair of idiosyncratic, ultraconservative House Republicans are risking the ire of the former president and his supporters to try to bolster the Florida governor.
content: Most House Republicans operate under an unspoken but ironclad rule: Do whatever you can to avoid provoking the wrath of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Driver in Custody After Crashing Into Gate Near the White House
description: The Secret Service said that the driver’s motives were still unclear, but that there was no threat to the White House complex or the public.
content: A driver crashed into an exterior gate near the White House shortly before 6 p.m. Monday and was taken into custody, the Secret Service said, adding that the agency was still investigating whether the crash was intentional.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: Filing in Georgia Trump Case Claims ‘Improper’ Relationship Between Prosecutors
description: A defendant in the election interference case is arguing that the district attorney overseeing it and a special prosecutor she hired should be disqualified.
content: A lawyer for one of the defendants charged along with former President Donald J. Trump in the Georgia election interference case said in a court filing on Monday that the district attorney overseeing the case, Fani T. Willis, had engaged in a “clandestine” relationship with the special prosecutor she hired to help handle it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Kate Christobek
title: N.R.A. Lawyer Distances Gun Group From LaPierre’s Lavish Spending
description: A lawyer for the National Rifle Association said that Wayne LaPierre’s actions did not embody the organization. Mr. LaPierre announced his resignation as the group’s leader last week.
content: A defense attorney for the National Rifle Association on Tuesday fought back against a civil suit by the State of New York, arguing that the actions of the N.R.A.’s leader, who spent fortunes on luxuries and travel, were not those of the organization itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Mark Mazzetti and Paul Mozur
title: Lawmakers Push U.S. to Consider Trade Limits With A.I. Giant Tied to China
description: A congressional committee made the demand of the Commerce Department after The Times reported on concerns among U.S. intelligence officials over the Emirati company, G42.
content: A U.S. congressional committee has asked the Commerce Department to look into whether a giant technology company controlled by the ruling family of the United Arab Emirates should be put under trade restrictions because of its ties to China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: While Defending Trump, Ramaswamy Insists He’s More Electable in the Fall
description: On the snowy campaign trail in Iowa, he said the “system” would keep Donald Trump from reaching the White House.
content: In northwestern Iowa on Monday, Vivek Ramaswamy addressed, unprompted, a question that has trailed him throughout his presidential bid: Why should voters choose him instead of Donald J. Trump, the former president whom he routinely and staunchly defends?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennie Livingston
title: The False Note in Bradley Cooper’s ‘Maestro’
description: The film celebrates Leonard Bernstein’s musical duality, but fails to seriously engage with his bisexuality.
content: There’s a heartbreaking scene in Bradley Cooper’s “Maestro,” about the marriage of the composer and conductor Leonard Bernstein (Cooper) to the actress Felicia Montealegre (Carey Mulligan), in which, as the couple argue in the bedroom of their Upper West Side apartment, Macy’s parade inflatables glide past the windows. A giant Snoopy echoes a Snoopy we saw in a family scene; it also gestures at the awkward gulf between Bernstein’s private and public lives, as if the musician himself were yet another helium-propelled icon from the Thanksgiving pantheon. Montealegre’s accusation, “Your truth is a [expletive] lie!” nails Bernstein’s privilege, condemning the habits and appetites he expects his family to tolerate and support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart and Jillian Weinberger
title: The Hard Truth of Israel’s Endgame in Gaza
description: Peter Beinart warns that the country is committing a sin that “cannot be atoned for.”
content: What are Israel’s plans for Gaza if it succeeds in expelling Hamas? In this audio essay, Peter Beinart argues that the country’s goal is very clear: to force Palestinians to leave. Beinart believes America’s blanket support of Israel makes it complicit in crimes against humanity. “I want U.S. diplomats to understand that the forced expulsion of a population or part of a population is a war crime,” Beinart says. “I want U.S. government officials to fear that this will be their legacy and to ensure that it’s not.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: A Missile, a Rocket or a Satellite? Chinese Flyover Sows Confusion in Taiwan.
description: A warning from Taiwan about a satellite, erroneously called a missile in English, raised concerns about Chinese harassment days before an election.
content: Taiwan’s defense ministry issued an urgent alert Tuesday about a Chinese satellite launched on a rocket flying over the island, an alarming message that interrupted the final days of campaigning before a major election and spurred accusations of a political ploy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Kellen Browning
title: To Win Iowa, Trump Turns to Allies Like Marjorie Taylor Greene
description: With the former president busy defending himself in court from 91 felony charges, his campaign has deployed high-profile conservatives to help fill the gaps in Iowa.
content: Less than a week before Iowans decide whether to slingshot Donald J. Trump toward another presidential nomination, his schedule looks like this: Go to Washington for an appeals court hearing on Tuesday. Pop into Iowa for a Fox News town-hall event on Wednesday — and then make an expected return to court on Thursday, this time in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu, Stuart A. Thompson and Steven Lee Myers
title: Elections and Disinformation Are Colliding Like Never Before in 2024
description: A wave of elections coincides with state influence operations, a surge of extremism, A.I. advances and a pullback in social media protections.
content: Billions of people will vote in major elections this year — around half of the global population, by some estimates — in one of the largest and most consequential democratic exercises in living memory. The results will affect how the world is run for decades to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Federal Judges Cast Doubt on Trump’s Claim of Immunity
description: Also, powerful storms across the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Tuesday.
content: Donald Trump appeared today in front of an appeals court panel in Washington to argue that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election because they arose from actions he took as president. The three judges on the panel seemed unconvinced, suggesting that they are unlikely to rule in the former president’s favor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: In the N.F.L. and at Big Companies, Diversity Playbooks Face Hurdles
description: The league’s successes and struggles are playing out in hundreds of companies that have emulated its Rooney Rule in trying to hire more people from underrepresented groups.
content: The end of the National Football League’s regular season on Sunday triggered the start of two annual events: the playoffs, and the period when a wave of teams fire head coaches and general managers and start frenzied searches for their replacements.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi and Mark Walker
title: 737 Max Inspections Delayed as Boeing Revises Guidance
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said that Boeing’s instructions for how airlines should check the planes were insufficient and that the company would revise them.
content: Federal regulators on Tuesday said Boeing was revising its instructions for how airlines should inspect its 737 Max 9, delaying the manufacturer’s effort to get the jet back in the air after a panel in one of the planes blew out during a flight late last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
title: A Glimpse Inside a Devastated Gaza
description: In the ruins of two Gazan towns, New York Times journalists witnessed the sheer destruction that Israel’s war has wrought and the devastation of Hamas’s operations.
content: For a few fleeting moments, the two-story house on the edge of Bureij, a ruined town in central Gaza, still felt like a Palestinian home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Yiwen Lu
title: No, That’s Not Taylor Swift Peddling Le Creuset Cookware
description: The singer did not promote a giveaway of the popular cookware, but an artificially generated version of her voice suggested otherwise.
content: Taylor Swift’s affinity for Le Creuset is real: Her collection of the cookware has been featured on a Tumblr account dedicated to the pop star’s home décor, showcased in her gift choices at a fan’s bridal shower and shown in a Netflix documentary that was highlighted by Le Creuset’s Facebook page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Pirates of Penzance,’ ‘English’ and ‘Yellow Face’ Bound for Broadway
description: Roundabout Theater Company, the biggest nonprofit on Broadway, said it would produce the three shows next season.
content: Roundabout Theater Company, the biggest nonprofit operating on Broadway, is planning to stage a jazz-inflected production of “The Pirates of Penzance,” Gilbert and Sullivan’s famed 19th-century comic operetta, in the spring of 2025, the organization said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Do You Wish You Could Do Well?
description: As a companion to our new “how to” contest, here are 10 questions to help you brainstorm some skills you’d like to learn, whether practical or just for fun.
content: Are you a karaoke enthusiast? If so, you might have a few tips to share about how to choose a song — for example, “just because you like it does not mean you should sing it.” (After all, not everybody has the vocal range for “Bohemian Rhapsody.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Trump Shows Little Emotion During Hearing, Then Says He ‘Did Nothing Wrong’
description: Mr. Trump, speaking at a Washington hotel he once owned, said that “you have to have immunity” as president. It was a core element of Tuesday’s hearing.
content: The small courtroom was already packed when former President Donald J. Trump walked slowly inside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx and Katherine Schulten
title: How to Write a ‘How-To’: A Step-by-Step Guide to Our Contest
description: We walk you through how to brainstorm a topic, interview an expert and write your own original “How to ….”
content: “If you want to know how to do something, don’t just search the internet,” advises Malia Wollan, the longtime writer of Tip, a how-to column that ran weekly in The New York Times Magazine for seven years. “Instead, find a person who already knows how and ask them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong and Vivian Nereim
title: Saudi-Israel Ties Depend on Steps Toward a Palestinian State, Blinken Says
description: In meetings with Israeli leaders, the U.S. secretary of state held out the prospect of Saudi recognition to prod Israel to curb combat operations in Gaza and accept a path to Palestinian statehood.
content: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, and a Saudi ambassador asserted on Tuesday the possibility of diplomatic recognition of Israel by Saudi Arabia if the Israeli government alleviates the suffering of residents of Gaza and puts Palestinians on a path toward statehood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong and Keith Collins
title: See How 2023 Shattered Records to Become the Hottest Year
description: Month after month global temperatures didn’t just break records, they surpassed them by far. This year could be even warmer.
content: The numbers are in, and scientists can now confirm what month after month of extraordinary heat worldwide began signaling long ago. Last year was Earth’s warmest by far in a century and a half.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Unity Software to Cut 25% of Its Work Force
description: The cuts follow a tough year in which the tech industry laid off tens of thousands of workers.
content: The videogame software provider Unity Software said on Monday that it would cut its work force by 25 percent, or roughly 1,800 jobs, in one of the first major tech industry layoffs this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Wesley Parnell
title: New York Begins Evicting Migrant Families Who Hit a Shelter Time Limit
description: On Tuesday, families with children had to pack up their belongings and either find somewhere else to live or line up to reapply for shelter beds.
content: Since arriving from Venezuela four months ago, Joana Rivas has slowly found some semblance of stability in New York City, picking up occasional cleaning jobs and enrolling her 9-year-old daughter at a public school in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Wingenroth
title: Three Dancers and Three Traditions Converse, United by Rhythm
description: Soles of Duende, a percussive dance trio appearing at the Joyce Theater this week, situates tap, flamenco and Kathak in joyful and thrilling conversation.
content: “Can We Dance Here?” That’s the title of Soles of Duende’s signature work. But it’s also a question that the members of this percussive dance company often find themselves posing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court, and a Glimpse Inside Gaza
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Be Wide-Open
description: Adam Wagner reveals his hidden agenda.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Paul Taylor Dance Company to Move to Midtown in Major Expansion
description: The renowned troupe will more than triple its footprint, growing its studio space and education programs.
content: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, founded in 1954 by the renowned choreographer, has long been one of the city’s most prominent troupes. But it has struggled in recent years to find space to match its ambitions for more performances, rehearsals, classes and community events.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Kyle Chayka
description: The Jan. 9, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Kyle Chayka. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal, Genevieve Glatsky and José María León Cabrera
title: Ecuador Plunges Into Crisis Amid Prison Riots and Gang Leader’s Disappearance
description: The president declared a state of emergency and ordered the military to “neutralize” dozens of gangs. Gunmen stormed a TV studio as cameras rolled.
content: Gunmen wearing masks stormed a television station in Ecuador’s largest city on Tuesday, taking anchors and staff hostage and exchanging gunfire with the police as cameras rolled before the intruders were subdued and arrested.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Immunity Claim in Court
description: The judges seem likely to reject a key element of Trump’s defense in the election case.
content: It looks like Donald Trump ran into a wall today while pushing his position that he cannot be charged criminally for his efforts to remain in power after losing the 2020 election. It came in the form of three federal appeals court judges.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 9, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Jan. 9, 2024.
content: An article on Friday about the low use of Paxlovid among eligible patients misspelled the name of the pharmaceutical company that makes the medication ensitrelvir. It is Shionogi, not Shinogi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: January’s Secret: It’s the Best Month
description: Once you see why, you may never want it to end.
content: Consider the plight of January, the sad sack of months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coqodaq, From the Cote Team, Is a Temple of Fried Chicken
description: The Korean Chinese restaurant Octo opens in Koreatown, Bibliotheque brings a book-lined wine den to Mercer Street and more restaurant news.
content: Beef or chicken? The restaurateur Simon Kim now has you covered either way. An owner of the Korean steakhouse Cote is opening what he calls a “fried chicken cathedral,” with a dining room framed by glowing, barrel-vaulted arches that disappear to infinity, thanks to a rear wall mirror. The design is by the Rockwell Group, involving David Rockwell’s personal touch. But the food is Mr. Kim’s idea, more than four years in the making, with the executive chef Seung Kyu Kim in charge (no relation to the owner, though the two met while working at Jean-Georges). Simon Kim’s notion is to offer a mix of American and Korean approaches to fried chicken and give it glamour with (supposedly) more sustainable ingredients in a more elegant setting. At Coqodaq it’s one-size-fits-all, a $38 dinner that includes chicken soup; a bucket of chicken parts fried in a gluten-free batter based on rice flour, chicken glazed with gochujang or soy and garlic; a cold perilla noodle dish; banchan, small dishes, that include palate-cleansing white radish; and soft serve frozen yogurt. Starters (extra) include some seafood options. The chickens are pasture-raised in Pennsylvania Amish country, and triple-fried in oil produced in Iowa from fermented Brazilian sugar cane. The name of the restaurant blends French, American and Korean words for chicken. The sommelier, Victoria James, who also curates the wines at Cote, has a wine list that features Champagne, which she and Mr. Kim agree is the ideal beverage for fried chicken. Her list offers 400 of them, and other sparklers by the glass and the bottle. Considering that fried chicken is finger-food, in the front of the restaurant, there’s a hand-washing area with three sinks. Some high-top tables near the entrance are for walk-ins, there’s a long bar, and garage doors will open to an outside patio in warmer weather. Tables at the leather-upholstered booths beneath the arches in the 190-seat room have lazy susans, the better for sharing. (Opens Friday)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: A Major Trump Hearing
description: A case before an appeals court in Washington could influence how the former president’s trials will play out this year.
content: Donald Trump’s four criminal trials can seem dizzying, including both federal and state cases, across Florida, Georgia, New York and Washington. But it’s worth remembering that the cases have different timetables. And any case that might produce a verdict before Election Day is probably more important than the others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Leigh Brown
title: For the Lakota, Creativity Thrives Where There’s No Word for Art
description: A Native-run studio, the Artspace is a beacon of hope, nurturing talent amid a resurgence of Indigenous traditions.
content: There is no word for art in the Lakota language. But the power of art, in every facet of life, has drawn a boisterous group of moccasin beaders, painters, regalia artists and producers of Native hip-hop down a two-lane road that undulates through the tawny hills of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation, eight miles from the nearest intersection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz and Ann Hinga Klein
title: More Than 1,000 Flights Are Canceled as Extreme Weather Batters the U.S.
description: The cancellations were felt most acutely in Chicago, where ice and snow briefly halted all flights on Tuesday afternoon. Airports elsewhere in the Midwest and the Northeast were also affected.
content: More than 1,000 domestic and international flights in the United States were canceled on Tuesday as extreme weather pummeled the country from coast to coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai, Christine Hauser and Jesus Jiménez
title: 3 Killed as Storms and Likely Tornadoes Tear Through Southeastern U.S.
description: Gusty winds ripped through the Florida Panhandle, downing power lines and trees. More than 12 million people were under tornado watches through Tuesday night.
content: At least three people died as severe thunderstorms, powerful winds and apparent tornadoes ripped across swaths of the southeastern United States on Tuesday, downing power lines and trees, and damaging buildings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Hilton Head Native Who Fought Developers to Save Family Land Dies at 94
description: Josephine Wright’s high-profile legal battle with a land developer on the picturesque South Carolina island drew support from Snoop Dogg, Kyrie Irving and Tyler Perry, among others.
content: A 94-year-old woman who was at the center of a legal battle with a developer to keep her family’s ancestral land on the island of Hilton Head, S.C., has died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: South Korea Bans Dog Meat, a Now-Unpopular Food
description: Breeding, killing and selling dogs for their meat will be banned in a country where it has fallen out of favor. Hundreds of thousands of the animal were still being bred for human consumption.
content: South Korea’s lawmakers on Tuesday outlawed the breeding, slaughter and sale of dogs for human consumption, a centuries-old practice that is unpopular and rare today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Gina Kolata
title: Austin Was Hospitalized for Complications From Prostate Cancer Surgery
description: A spokesman said the White House, which had been kept in the dark for three days about the defense secretary’s hospitalization, only learned of the diagnosis on Tuesday.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III has been hospitalized for the past week because of complications after he had prostate cancer surgery, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center said in a statement on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Surprised by New Details About Austin’s Health, White House Orders Review
description: The president learned only Tuesday that his defense secretary had been diagnosed with prostate cancer a month ago and had surgery under general anesthesia in December, aides said.
content: The White House was caught off guard once again on Tuesday when it learned that Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III had been diagnosed with prostate cancer a month ago and had surgery to treat the disease under general anesthesia on Dec. 22 without notifying either President Biden or his staff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones, Derrick Bryson Taylor and Ed Shanahan
title: New York Region Is Under High Wind Warning as Forecasters Warn of Flooding
description: Authorities in New York and the surrounding area are warning residents to prepare for treacherous weather from Tuesday night into Wednesday.
content: A major coastal storm will bring excessive rain and damaging winds to New York City and the surrounding area from late Tuesday until midday Wednesday, the National Weather Service said. The strongest winds were expected from 10 p.m. until 3 a.m., with gusts of up to 70 m.p.h. were along the coast. A citywide flood watch was in effect until noon Wednesday, and widespread power outages were expected
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Johnatan Reiss
title: Israel, Shifting War Tempo, Tailors Its Messages for Home and Abroad
description: Israeli officials have told foreign journalists that they are starting to slow military operations in Gaza, while assuring the Israeli public that the war against Hamas will go on.
content: With a vast chasm between how Israelis see the war in Gaza and how much of the world does, Israel’s leaders have taken to adopting different rhetoric when addressing the two audiences about how its military campaign against Hamas will be conducted over the year ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño
title: Breathing Their Way to an Altered State
description: As psychedelics move from the underground to mainstream medicine, clinicians aspiring to work in the field are inducing altered states with deep breathing.
content: The instructions were simple: Lying on cots while wearing eyeshades, participants were directed to take deep belly breaths without pause to the beat of fast-paced music booming from loudspeakers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Hall
title: The New Space Race Is Causing New Pollution Problems
description: Earth’s stratosphere has never seen the amounts of emissions and waste from rockets and satellites that a booming space economy will leave behind.
content: The high-altitude chase started over Cape Canaveral on Feb. 17, 2023, when a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket launched. Thomas Parent, a NASA research pilot, was flying a WB-57 jet when the rocket ascended past the right wing — leaving him mesmerized before he hit the throttle to accelerate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The Best State Parks to Visit This Winter
description: Stargaze in the desert, see elephant seals and more.
content: With the new year come wonderful new opportunities to explore the Golden State.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Weinstein
title: Five (Easy, Fun, Quick and Completely Delicious) Weeknight Dishes
description: I’m in cook mode right now. What I’m making: blistered broccoli pasta, chana masala and build-your-own poke bowls.
content: I’m in cook mode right now in this blissful post-holiday lull, staying in more often and making more food, too: waffles and squash soup, kimchi tuna salad and rainbow sprinkle cake. (And dinner, of course. There’s always dinner.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
title: 5 Takeaways From the Appeals Court Hearing on Trump’s Immunity Claim
description: A ruling by the court, and the timing of its decision, could be a major factor in determining when, or even whether, the former president will go to trial in the federal election case.
content: A three-judge panel of the federal appeals court in Washington heard arguments on Tuesday in a momentous case over former President Donald J. Trump’s claim that he is immune from criminal charges for the efforts he took to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Rabin
title: ‘Fauda’ Actor Is Seriously Injured Fighting in Gaza
description: The actor, Idan Amedi, underwent surgery to remove shrapnel from his body and was expected to recover, Israeli news media reported.
content: An Israeli soldier who is an actor in the popular Israeli series “Fauda” on Netflix was seriously wounded when a truck filled with explosives blew up in the Bureij area of central Gaza on Monday, the Israeli military said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Coveted Cup
description: The latest phone? Special-edition sneakers? A trendy tumbler? What would you be willing to camp out — even fight — for?
content: Have you heard about people camping out for and fighting over a special Valentine’s Day cup at Target stores? Yes, a cup!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: What Songs Would ‘Saltburn’ Characters Have Spun in 2007?
description: The soundtrack to Emerald Fennell’s movie has been a talker. Hear tracks by M.I.A., Girl Talk, Nelly Furtado and others that would have been a good fit.
content: Over the weekend, I finally watched “Saltburn,” the provocative, polarizing and occasionally downright icky coming-of-age thriller that no one can stop talking about right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyndie Chiou
title: How Astronomers Are Saving Astronomy From Satellites — For Now
description: Even the most powerful telescopes are in peril as orbits above Earth fill with thousands of new satellites. But scientists aren’t ready to give up the night sky.
content: In December 2020, astronomers documented a burst of highly energetic light in one of the most distant galaxies ever observed. But less than a year later, the paper’s claims lay in limbo. Other scientists said it had merely been a passing satellite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: France Gets Its Youngest and First Openly Gay Prime Minister
description: Gabriel Attal, 34, replaces Élisabeth Borne in a cabinet shuffle that President Emmanuel Macron hopes can reinvigorate a term marked by drift and division.
content: In a typically bold bid to revitalize his second term, President Emmanuel Macron named Gabriel Attal, 34, as his new prime minister, replacing Élisabeth Borne, 62, who made no secret of the fact that she was unhappy to be forced out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump says he hopes any economic crash happens in 2024 so he isn’t blamed.
description: Former President Trump said Monday night that he hoped any downturn would come before his possible re-election — under President Biden’s administration.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said in an interview on Monday that he believed the economy would crash — and that he hoped it would happen in the next year so the blame would fall on President Biden’s administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: What happens next in Trump’s immunity case?
description: The court has already moved the case along at an exceptionally brisk pace and is expected to make its decision fairly quickly by the standards of a typical appeal.
content: A federal appeals court in Washington has now heard arguments on former President Donald J. Trump’s sweeping claim that he is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Sinead O’Connor Died of Natural Causes, Coroner Says
description: The Irish singer-songwriter, known for her powerful, evocative voice, died at 56 at a residence in London in July.
content: A London coroner’s office said Tuesday that the Irish singer Sinead O’Connor died from natural causes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: For Anti-Trump Republicans, It All Might Come Down to New Hampshire
description: With the Iowa caucuses likely to be a battle for second place, the next nominating state appears to offer the best chance of an upset defeat of Donald Trump.
content: With his usual bluntness, Chris Christie used a recent event in New Hampshire to lay out why he thought the state’s primary election was more important than the Iowa caucuses — and what he saw as its tremendous stakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas J. R. White and Alan Burdick
title: ‘The Trees Saved Me’
description: In Romania, a walk in the woods blossomed into a mission to safeguard centuries-old beeches and the history that shaped them.
content: The story of the Forest of Immortal Stories begins not so long ago, in 2019, when Elena-Mirela Cojocaru, beloved wife of Ion Cojocaru, mayor of the hamlet of Nucsoara, died after a struggle with cancer. Mr. Cojocaru himself soon fell ill with a heart ailment; as a remedy his doctor told him to walk in the countryside, 6,000 or more steps a day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: U.S. Naval Officer Who Helped China Is Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison
description: Wenheng Zhao pleaded guilty to charges that he sent photos of American military installations and details of U.S. military exercises to an intelligence officer working for China.
content: A United States naval officer who sent an intelligence officer working for the Chinese government photos of American military installations and details of naval training exercises in Asia was sentenced to more than two years in prison on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Tony Fortuna, Restaurateur With a Congenial Flair, Dies at 76
description: He turned running a dining room into a fine art at each of his restaurants over a 40-year career, most notably TBar on the Upper East Side.
content: Tony Fortuna, a longtime Manhattan restaurateur who turned running a dining room into a fine art as a consummate host who treated customers as friends, died on Friday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett and Benjamin Mueller
title: The F.D.A. Warned an Asthma Drug Could Induce Despair. Many Were Never Told.
description: Singulair, now a generic, is still used by millions of people in the United States even after thousands of patients and dozens of studies have described harm.
content: In early 2020, the Food and Drug Administration responded to decades of escalating concerns about a commonly prescribed drug for asthma and allergies by deploying one of its most potent tools: a stark warning on the drug’s label that it could cause aggression, agitation and even suicidal thoughts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: New Year’s Resolutions for the Anxious
description: Here’s how to confront your fears and seek out new perspectives this year — no therapist required.
content: The start of the new year often brings lofty ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Fading Online Celebrity of George Santos
description: Inside the halls of power, his performance worked for a time. Outside, he’s a flop.
content: George Santos was expelled from Congress on a Friday in December. On the next business day, he announced a new role: as a kind of clown-for-hire on Cameo, an app and website where he offered his services recording personalized videos for fans. First he priced the messages at $75 each, but soon he was charging $200, then $400, then $500 a pop. But last week, the market contracted. The videos dropped to $350 apiece.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr

description: A town hall in Iowa on Wednesday is the network’s first live interview with the former president in nearly two years, the latest twist in a long-running drama.
content: One of television’s longest-running soap operas is about to start a new chapter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Gooden
title: Tired of Meditation? Try Looking for Clams.
description: For those of us who have difficulty finding peace while sitting in one place, clamming can be an unexpected escape.
content: On these dark winter evenings, when the end of the day has crept up all too quickly and both of my children are speaking to me at once while I’m trying to follow a recipe and my laptop is still open with incomplete work, I find myself daydreaming of summer. I think of the one activity and place that quiets my mind and restores my drained reserves: clamming on Cape Cod, which is foraging for clams, from large quahogs that can be baked or used for chowder to — my favorite — smaller ones, the so-called littleneck clams, that you eat raw that same day at cocktail hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage

content: With the help of lightning rings, garlic and Bibles, players were outlasting waves of ghouls and beasts in Vampire Survivors long before the video game was released officially.
